story.title: The Christmas Sweater - Episode 5
story.storyDescription: Ever since her motherâ€™s death, Noelle hasnâ€™t wanted to go home for the holidays. But perhaps a bit of holiday magic is all she needsâ€¦
story.creator: web-uploader
story.prePaywallNotification: Noelle is about to be floored by Beatriceâ€™s story, which involved THE CHRISTMAS SWEATER. Read it in the next episode.
story.postPaywallNotification: Is THE CHRISTMAS SWEATER truly magical? ðŸŽ„âœ¨ Read the rest of the story to find out.

messages.text: Wearing the magical sweater, Noelle walks out of the house and shuts the door behind her.
The playful ring of the jingle bells on her familyâ€™s wreath puts a spring in her step as she heads into town.
She makes a pit stop at her favorite cafÃ© for a sweet gingerbread latteâ€¦
And is stopped in her tracks by the sight of a familiar face.
Are you here to steal my eggnog again?
What?! What are you doing here?
Visiting my aunt. This is where Iâ€™m celebrating the holidays this year.
Really? Me too. I grew up in this town.
No kidding!
Lawrence flashes her his trademark devilish grin.
And Noelle feels herself melt all over again.
So as a kid, did you need alone time during the holidays too?
Noelle tilts her head.
Actually, no. When I was younger, I was the queen of the holidays in my house.
Her smile bursts free at the memory.
Oh yeah?
He glances at her sweater.
Well, Iâ€™m happy to see your holiday spirit coming back.
The two lock eyes for a minute and Noelle feels the ground fall out beneath her feet.
Lawrenceâ€™s irises are impossibly green.
Soâ€¦what does the queen of the holidays do?
Sheâ€™s in charge of everything â€” the decorating, the baking, the dinner menusâ€¦
Lawrence raises his eyebrows and smiles.
I didnâ€™t realize there were multiple dinner menus.
Noelle canâ€™t stop smiling.
Then you havenâ€™t truly celebrated the holidays.
You HAVE to plan multiple menus.
Otherwise, you could end up with something terrible like canned cranberry sauce.
I happen to like canned cranberry sauce.
No one likes canned cranberry sauce after theyâ€™ve tried my homemade stuff.
Lawrence holds Noelleâ€™s gaze for another heated moment.
Then his eyes drop down to her mouth. His tongue swipes across his lower lip.
When he finds his voice, it comes out deep and husky.
I guess Iâ€™ll have to try it then.
Desire fills Noelleâ€™s entire body â€” she can hardly speak.
After a few false starts, she finally forms a coherent sentence.
I â€” um, I should probably get my latte and get going.
Thereâ€™s someone I need to see.
Noelle ducks her head and turns toward the counter.
But she doesnâ€™t even take two steps before a large, warm hand encircles her own.
Noelle turns around, and looks into Lawrenceâ€™s earnest eyes.
Come to dinner with me tonight?
Please?
I know you like your alone time at the holidays, but I thinkâ€”
Yes.
What?
Iâ€™d love to have dinner with you. Yes.
An image of her favorite restaurant, the cozy and romantic Wellington Room, flashes through her head.
And I know just the place.
Well, since this is my first time in Portsmouthâ€¦
Iâ€™m glad youâ€™re taking the lead, Christmas Queen.
Noelle laughs.
You wonâ€™t regret it.
Then, almost twenty-four hours after meeting himâ€¦
Noelle finally gives Lawrence her number.
She tries not to skip as she walks up to the counter, grabs her latte, and strides out the door.
Maybeâ€¦just maybeâ€¦this Christmas sweater is magical after all.
Smiling, she strolls down the street, stopping to leave money for the Salvation Army Santa.
And then she enters Beatriceâ€™s quaint shop.
For the first time since childhood, she sees it for the wonder that it isâ€¦
Floor to ceiling cedar bookshelves line the walls, chock-full of all of Noelleâ€™s favorite stories.
Perhaps she and Beatrice have something in common after allâ€¦
Good morning, Beatrice.
I came to apologize for yesterday.
Oh, honey! You donâ€™t have toâ€”
No, really. Iâ€™m an adult and I was acting like a child.
I heard the good news about you and my dad andâ€¦
I think itâ€™s great.
Beatrice places the stack of books sheâ€™s holding on the counter.
They hit the hard wood with a distinguished smack.
Letâ€™s sit in the leather chairs, okay?
Iâ€™ve been wanting to have a proper chit-chat with you.
She points to the best reading seats in the shop.
Noelle smiles, remembering the times she and Maria used to cozy into one oversized chair togetherâ€¦
Even when there were two seats free.
She and her sister just always wanted to be next to each other.
Beatrice flips the â€œOpenâ€ sign to â€œClosedâ€ and then joins Noelle.
I think this conversation warrants no distractions.
Noelle smiles.
I think you might be right.
Iâ€™m so sorry for the way I spoke to you.
Beatrice takes Noelleâ€™s hands.
For the first time in five years, Noelle doesnâ€™t shirk away from her touch.
Thank you, dear.
I forgive you.
Noelle sighs. She feels a weight lift off her chest.
As much as I appreciate that youâ€™re opening up to the idea of your father and me togetherâ€¦
I know that you wonâ€™t just be able to accept it overnight.
Beatrice pats Noelleâ€™s hands gentlyâ€¦
And Noelle feels her tense shoulders relax.
Thanks Beatrice. I really want to be ready to see you and my dad together, but Iâ€¦
I just loved my mom so much.
I did too.
Thatâ€™s why it took me such a long time to even consider a relationship with your father.
What?! But you guys got together only one year after my Momâ€™s death!
Yes, but a year is a long time for two old folks like us.
Dating at this age is different. Itâ€™s easier to know what you want.
And, especially in your fatherâ€™s case, what you need.
Noelle tries to hide the confusion on her face.
I can see that Iâ€™m not being very clear.
Let me step back.
It all starts with a story about the sweater youâ€™re wearing.
This sweater?
Yes. That sweater used to belong to your mother.
